Götte, MD, PHD, a Albert C. van Rossum, MD, PHD, a Niels van Royen, MD, PHD, a,f Robin Nijveldt, MD, PHD a,f ABSTRACT OBJECTIVES This study sought to determine the agreement between cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging and invasive measurements of fractional flow reserve (FFR) in the evaluation of nonculprit lesions after ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). In addition, we investigated whether fully quantitative analysis of myocardial perfusion is superior to semiquantitative and visual analysis.BACKGROUND The agreement between CMR and FFR in the evaluation of nonculprit lesions in patients with STEMI with multivessel disease is unknown.METHODS Seventy-seven patients with STEMI with at least 1 intermediate (diameter stenosis 50% to 90%) nonculprit lesion underwent CMR and invasive coronary angiography in conjunction with FFR measurements at 1 month after primary intervention. The imaging protocol included stress and rest perfusion, cine imaging, and late gadolinium enhancement. Fully quantitative, semiquantitative, and visual analysis of myocardial perfusion were compared against a reference of FFR. Hemodynamically obstructive was defined as FFR #0.80. RESULTS Hemodynamically obstructive nonculprit lesions were present in 31 (40%) patients. Visual analysis displayed an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.74 (95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.62 to 0.83), with a sensitivity of 73% and a specificity of 70%. For semiquantitative analysis, the relative upslope of the stress signal intensity time curve and the relative upslope derived myocardial flow reserve had respective AUCs of 0.66 (95% CI: 0.54 to 0.77) and 0.71 (95% CI: 0.59 to 0.81). Fully quantitative analysis did not augment diagnostic performance (all p > 0.05). Stress myocardial blood flow displayed an AUC of 0.76 (95% CI: 0.64 to 0.85), with a sensitivity of 69% and a specificity of 77%. Similarly, MFR displayed an AUC of 0.82 (95% CI: 0.71 to 0.90), with a sensitivity of 82% and a specificity of 71%. CONCLUSIONS CMR and FFR have moderate-good agreement in the evaluation of nonculprit lesions in patients with STEMI with multivessel disease. Fully quantitative, semiquantitative, and visual analysis yield similar diagnostic performance. (J Am Coll Cardiol Img 2020;13:715-28) © 2020 by the American College of Cardiology Foundation. O ver the past few decades, cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging has emerged as a robust tool to evaluate patients with suspected obstructive coronary artery disease (CAD). Among the myriad of imaging techniques, CMR has the advantages of being cost-effective (1), widely available, and multiparametric (i.e., it allows to evaluate several pathological features during a single session). In addition, CMR does not expose patients to ionizing radiation while permitting imaging at high spatial resolution. Finally, patients with normal CMR results have a reassuring low risk of future cardiovascular events (2). In the clinical setting, perfusion images are typically assessed visually; however, CMR can also quantify myocardial blood flow (MBF) in relative (semiquantitative) (3) and even absolute terms (fully quantitative) (4). Conflicting evidence exists as to whether quantification improves the diagnostic accuracy of perfusion CMR. Although some studies reported superiority of fully quantitative analysis over semiquantitative and visual analysis (5), others found no benefit of quantification in the diagnosis of obstructive CAD (6-8). In patients with stable CAD, invasive measurements of fractional flow reserve (FFR) are considered the optimal index for diagnosing hemodynamically obstructive CAD and guiding revascularization (9). Although CMR and FFR are reported to have a high concordance in the assessment of patients with stable CAD (10), the agreement between CMR and FFR in the evaluation of nonculprit lesions after ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is still unknown.

This is a substudy of data from patients enrolled in the REDUCE-MVI (Reducing Micro Vascular Dysfunction in Acute Myocardial Infarction by Ticagrelor) trial in the Amsterdam UMC, location VUmc. The main results of this trial have been published previously (13). Briefly, patients with a first STEMI and at least 1 intermediate lesion in a nonculprit vessel were enrolled after successful revascularization of the culprit. Intermediate was defined as 50% to 90% diameter stenosis. The main exclusion criteria were cardiogenic shock, decompensated heart failure, left main disease, and chronic total occlusion. Acute STEMI management and subsequent medical care followed contemporary guidelines (14). Follow-up CMR and invasive assessment were scheduled 1 month after the index event. CMR always preceded invasive assessment. Patients were instructed to refrain from products containing caffeine or xanthine for 24 h before the follow-up visit. To evaluate angina burden, patients completed the Seattle Angina Questionnaire (SAQ) upon arrival at the hospital (15). The study protocol was approved by the institutional review committee of the Amsterdam UMC, location VUmc. All patients gave written informed consent. CMR IMAGE ACQUISITION. To assess the arterial input function, low-resolution turboFLASH images were acquired at the basal level using a sequence optimized for the high gadolinium concentration. Perfusion images were obtained every heartbeat for 50 to 70 cardiac cycles following intravenous injection of a 0.075 mmol/kg bolus of a gadoliniumbased contrast agent (DOTAREM, Guerbet, Villepinte, France). In-plane respiratory motion of the heart was corrected using a nonrigid registration (17). Perfusion images were corrected for surface coil induced inhomogeneities through a separate prescan normalization (18). Typical in-plane resolution of the myocardial perfusion images was 2.5 Â 2.5 mm, with a slice thickness of 10 mm (prepulse 90 , repetition time 5.6 ms, echo time 1.1 ms, saturation time 110 ms, flip angle 18 , matrix 144 Â 160). Stress was induced by continuous infusion of adenosine at 140 mg/kg/min through a second venous cannula, started 2 min before image acquisition. Rest perfusion images were obtained 15 min after stress imaging using identical scanning parameters and slice location. Cardiac function was assessed in between stress and rest perfusion with steady-state free-precession cine imaging. Late gadolinium enhancement (LGE) was performed 12 to 15 min after rest perfusion using a 2-dimensional segmented inversion-recovery gradient-echo pulse sequence. CMR IMAGE ANALYSIS. Perfusion images were analyzed using dedicated research software (MASS version 2017-Exp, Leiden, the Netherlands). Cine and LGE images were analyzed using commercially available software (QMASS version 7.6, Medis, Leiden, the Netherlands). The myocardium was divided into 16 segments (true apex not included), which were allocated to vascular territories using anatomic information from the invasive angiogram. In addition to this modified segmentation, myocardial segments were allocated to vascular territories according to the standard segmentation model of the American Heart Association (19). Visual analysis of perfusion images was performed by consensus of 2 expert observers (R.N. and R.L.). First, quality of the images was graded as 0 (not assessable), 1 (poor), 2 (moderate), or 3 (good). Next, the occurrence of splenic switch-off was visually assessed by comparing the rest and stress perfusion images. Thereafter, perfusion was scored per segment as 0 (normal), 1 (mildly abnormal), or 2 (severely abnormal). LGE images were reviewed alongside perfusion images to evaluate hyperenhancement. The transmural extent of hyperenhancement was scored per segment as: 0 (absent)of the individual segments. Because the region of hyperenhancement resulting from the recent STEMI may exceed the segments allocated to the culprit (20), all hyperenhanced segments were excluded provided that the hyperenhancement was clearly related to the index event. Segments with hyperenhancement according to a nonischemic pattern were also excluded (21); thus, segments in nonculprit vascular territories with incidental hyperenhancement were only included if the hyperenhancement was clearly unrelated to the index event and demonstrated an ischemic pattern. Semiand fully quantitative analysis of perfusion were performed by a single observer (H.E.), supervised by a second observer (R.N.). Endocardial and epicardial contours were manually drawn on the basal, mid, and apical slices of both the stress and rest perfusion series. A region of interest was placed in the blood pool of the perfusion series obtained for the arterial input function. Semiquantitative analysis of myocardial perfusion was performed by calculating the relative upslope of the signal intensity time curve, as described previously (3). Fully quantitative analysis was performed by Fermi function constrained deconvolution of the signal intensity time curves according to previously described methods (4). Myocardial flow reserve (MFR) was calculated as the ratio of stress to rest perfusion parameters. Perfusion in myocardium subtended by a nonculprit vessel was calculated by averaging 2 adjacent segments with the lowest perfusion values in the vascular territory of the nonculprit vessel. In an additional analysis,perfusion was calculated by averaging the entire vascular territory of the nonculprit vessel. Remote myocardium was defined as the myocardial segments vascularized by a nonculprit vessel with <50% diameter stenosis. LV end-diastolic volume, endsystolic volume, and ejection fraction were calculated from the cine images. Infarct size was calculated from the LGE images using the full width at half maximum method. Additionally, the LGE images were evaluated for presence of microvascular obstruction. All CMR analyses were performed blinded to clinical information, coronary angiography results, and data obtained from invasive measurements. FOLLOW-UP INVASIVE CORONARY ANGIOGRAPHY AND PHYSIOLOGICAL INTERROGATION. A guiding catheter was advanced into the coronary ostium of the stenotic nonculprit vessel. After regular coronary 200 mg of nitrates were administered as an intracoronary bolus. A pressure/temperature sensor-tipped guidewire (PressureWire X wired, Abbott, Chicago, Illinois) was placed in the distal part of the stenotic nonculprit vessel and connected to the RadiAnalyzer interface (Abbott). Next, hyperemia was induced through intravenous infusion of adenosine using the same protocol as applied during CMR. FFR was obtained after at least 2 min of infusion. Their worse prognosis is possibly associated with additional plaque instability, impaired epicardial and microvascular myocardial perfusion, and cardiogenic shock. Primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) has been shown to improve prognosis in acute STEMI, yet nonculprit lesions identified during acute MI may be overestimated because of vasospasm, hemodynamic instability, and concurrent infusion of vasoactive substances (1). Targeted revascularization of prognostically important nonculprit lesions is therefore potentially attractive from patient outcome and cost-effectiveness perspectives. Fractional flow reserve (FFR)-guided PCI is considered the gold standard for the prognostic management of intermediate lesions in stable angina but requires maximal hyperemia and is comparatively time consuming. Establishing the diagnostic performance of cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) in this scenario could be seen as a valid first step, given the superior performance of stress perfusion CMR compared with other noninvasive imaging modalities in stable angina and its noninferiority compared with FFR (2). In this issue of iJACC, Everaars et al. (3) report moderate-to-good agreement of same-day adenosine stress perfusion CMR with invasive measurements of FFR a month following primary PCI for acute STEMI in 77 patients with nonculprit stenoses. The accuracy of visual, semiquantitative, and fully quantitative assessment of stress CMR did not differ significantly. In principle, acute microvascular dysfunction (from thrombus or leukocyte plugs, hemorrhage, microcirculatory compression, and neurohumoral vasoconstriction) could extend into nonculprit territory. This might limit maximal hyperemia with adenosine, resulting in higher FFR, particularly in large infarcts. To address this, Everaars et al. (3) measured thermodilution-derived coronary flow reserve and index of microcirculatory resistance in a subset of patients (68% of the nonculprit stenosed vessels) to identify any persisting microvascular dysfunction as a confounder of stress-perfusion accuracy. Did stress CMR underperform when compared with the stable angina setting? The areas under the curve (AUC) here were reported to be 0.74 (visual), 0.66 for stress-relative upslope, and 0.71 for relative upslopederived myocardial flow reserve (semiquantitative), and stress myocardial blood flow and myocardial flow reserve of 0.76 and 0.82 (fully quantitative). In contrast, a 15-study meta-analysis of diagnostic stress CMR accuracy in stable angina quoted an overall AUC against FFR in 1,830 vessels of 0.95 (4). Well-conducted comparisons of FFR and stress CMR in this group of patients remain limited. Stress CMR at 1.5-T in a smaller STEMI cohort was previously referenced against quantitative coronary angiography (QCA) rather than FFR. FIGREF97.text: Eike Nagel, MD, PHD, a,b Koen Nieman, MD, PHD c I t remains hotly debated, whether anatomical or functional investigation of patients with coronary artery disease is superior(1). Although trials in patients with low prevalence of disease have not been able to demonstrate differences(2), the question has less frequently been studied in patients with high prevalence of disease or known disease, such as patients after previous revascularization. Anatomical imaging of the coronary arteries using computed tomography angiography (CTA) has a very high negative predictive value in patients with low burden of disease, which is the main reason for its recommendation as an early test to rule out disease. In contrast, cases of patients with known or previously revascularized cor-onary artery disease are significantly more complex, challenging the role of noninvasive coronary artery imaging. These challenges are a higher calcium score in patients with risk factors or expressed disease, a larger percentage of intermediate stenosis with unknown hemodynamic significance, more stents or bypass vessels with complex anastomoses, a higher prevalence of previous myocardial infarction, and a higher burden of cardiac arrhythmia in patients with coronary artery disease. Most of these factors have a significant potential to reduce the accuracy of coronary artery imaging as well as computed tomography based fractional flow reserve (CT-FFR) but, except for previous myocardial infarction, have less or no influence on the direct measurement of myocardial perfusion. Assessment of myocardial perfusion has been a domain of nuclear imaging for decades; however, more recently, a large body of evidence has demonstrated that perfusion cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) has high accuracy, strong prognostic value, and the ability to reduce unnecessary catheterization (3). In a randomized clinical effectiveness trial (MR-INFORM [Myocardial Perfusion CMR versus Angiography and Fractional Flow Reserve to Guide the Management of Patients with Stable Coronary Artery Disease]), perfusion CMR was compared to invasive angiography and FFR to guide patient management, resulting in a lower rate of revascularization with similar outcome (4). These data pose perfusion CMR at the forefront of the workup of patients with intermediate to high pre-test likelihoods. Perfusion CT has struggled to find its place in the clinical routine for a number of reasons. Technical limitations required imaging several heart beats to obtain full coverage of the myocardium. On the other hand, perfusion CT found itself in direct competition with CT-FFR, which can be applied to regular CT angiograms without the need for additional imaging, as well as with perfusion CMR, which is free from ionizing radiation, does not require iodinated contrast agents, provides a better temporal resolution, and informs of the presence of previous myocardial infarction. In this issue of iJACC, Andreini et al. (5) assess an important niche area, the use of perfusion CT in patients with suspected in-stent restenosis. They assessed 163 patients who had previously undergone stent implantation and had indications for invasive angiography. Thirteen patients were excluded due to previous myocardial infarction (n ¼ 4), contraindication to adenosine (n ¼ 4), impaired renal function (n ¼ 3), and body mass index (n ¼ 2). All patients underwent CTA, which also served as a rest perfusion SEE PAGE 732 scan and adenosine stress perfusion CT using a static acquisition approach.

This was a post hoc substudy of the PACIFIC (Prospective Comparison of Cardiac PET/CT, SPECT/CT Perfusion Imaging and CT Coronary Angiography With Invasive Coronary Angiography) trial involving 208 patients who underwent coronary CT angiography, single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT), and positron emission tomography (PET) with interrogation by FFR of all coronary arteries (NCT01521468) (20). Patients prospectively underwent all non-invasive imaging and ICA with intracoronary measurements within 2 weeks, regardless of the imaging results. In the present substudy, only patients were included with measurements available of invasive flow indices during resting and hyperemic conditions. Patients were suspected of having stable CAD and had a normal left ventricular function. Exclusion criteria incorporated a history of CAD, signs of prior myocardial infarction, atrial fibrillation, renal failure, second-or third-degree atrioventricular block, or symptomatic asthma. The study complied with the Declaration of Helsinki and the study protocol was approved by the (Vrije Universiteit Medical Center) Medical Ethics Review Committee. All patients provided written informed consent. CORONARY CT ANGIOGRAPHY. CT scans were performed using a standard scanning protocol, with a section collimation of 2 Â 128 Â 0.625 mm, a gantry rotation time of 270 ms, and tube current between 200 and 360 mAs at 120 kV, primarily adjusting mAs based on body habitus. The scan was typically triggered using an automatic bolus-tracking technique and prospective electrocardiogram gating was used at 75% of the R-R interval, whereas -5% and þ5% were also available for interpretation.ASSESSMENT OF CORONARY PLAQUES. As previously described, all coronary segments with a diameter $2 mm were assessed by an experienced reader without the knowledge of invasive physiological results(14). The coronary tree was evaluated according to a 17-segment coronary artery model using axial, multiplanar reformation, maximum intensity projection, and cross-sectional images.Stenosis severity was graded as no stenosis, 1% to 49%, 50% to 69%, and $70%. Coronary artery calcium score was calculated according to the Agatston scoring system using Agatston units. Per vessel plaque volume was quantified automatically within manually designated regions of atherosclerotic plaque. Coronary lesions were also analyzed for 4 highrisk atherosclerotic plaque characteristics that have been described as predictors of worse outcome(10,21). The remodeling index was computed as the ratio of vessel area at the site of the maximal lesion to that of a proximal reference point, with an index >1.1 representing positive remodeling (PR)(12).Low attenuation plaque (LAP) was defined as a plaque containing any voxel <30 HU(12). Spotty calcification (SC) was characterized by a calcified plaque comprising <90 of the vessel circumference and <3 mm in length(12). The napkin ring sign (NRS) was defined by a plaque core with low CT attenuation surrounded by a rim-like area of higher CT attenuation(21). A high-risk plaque was defined by the presence of at least 1 of these 4 plaque characteristics.

Statistical differences between AUCs were compared using DeLong's test, without accounting for multiple observations within individuals (25). This is supported by previous and current findings of morphological plaque features as independent predictors for hyperemic hemodynamic repercussions(12)(13)(14).Although traditionally hyperemia is induced in the hemodynamic evaluation of lesions and subsequent revascularization decision making, iFR has recently emerged as an adenosine-free alternative(22). Two important randomized controlled trials recently reported that iFR guidance and FFR guidance resulted in a similar composite outcome of death, MI, and urgent revascularization(17,18). Although the study populations were remarkably large, the number of adverse events at 1-year follow-up were limited and driven by urgent revascularization. A pooled analysis of these data, however, revealed a numerical excess of death and MI in the iFR group which was not statistically significant and, therefore, hypothesis generating(19). As such, it remained unclear whether non-hyperemic assessment with iFR is associated with plaque vulnerability similar to FFR and became the impetus for the current substudy. For the other 2indices that were tested in the present study, Pd/Pa and iFRa, there was no prognostic data available.HIGH-RISK ATHEROSCLEROTICPLAQUES. Early pathological studies demonstrated that ruptured plaques were responsible for most fatal MIs(29) andled to the concept of so-called vulnerable plaques. These plaques are characterized by large lipid-rich cores, a myriad of inflammatory cells, and a thin fibrous cap(8,9). Due to recent advances, atherosclerotic plaque morphology can now be assessed in vivo with invasive and non-invasive imaging techniques(9,30). In this way, the prospective PROSPECT (Providing Regional Observations to StudyPredictors of Events in the Coronary Tree) studyshowed that lesion-related risk factors derived from intravascular ultrasound included small luminal area, thin-cap fibroatheromas, and large plaque burden(31). Plaques with these 3 adverse characteristics demonstrated a 18.2% likelihood of causing a major adverse cardiovascular event within a 3-year followup, while it should be noted that most events were rehospitalizations for unstable or progressive angina. Likewise, several plaque features derived from coronary CT have been identified as being high-risk for adverse events beyond stenosis severity (10,11,21). Especially large lipid-rich (low-attenuation on CT) and positively remodeled plaques were associated with the highest event rate of 22.5% within 2 years (10), as opposed to patients free of both high-risk plaque features, who had a very low risk of acute events (<0.5%) (10). Because the aforementioned studies did not include functional measures of atherosclerosis, the present results might partially fill this gap, even though in turn clinical outcome was currently not available. FIGREF110.text: adding intracoronary resting pressure indices in the evaluation of plaque features.Although the exact mechanisms have to be elucidated, some pathophysiological mechanisms could be considered as possible explanations.FFR is defined as the ratio of distal coronary pressure to aortic pressure across a stenosis measured during maximal hyperemia, which has been described to be affected by stenosis severity as well as severalother factors. Total coronary pressure drop is defined by the sum of the viscous friction along the entrance of a lesion, and losses induced by convective acceleration along the lesion. Both effects increase congruent with coronary flow. These local pressure losses are not recovered at the lesion exit due to flow separation and eddy formation (32). It is, therefore, advised to position the pressure wire as distal to the stenosis as technically feasible (33). Possibly, the morphology of high-risk plaques might have an incremental impact on such pressure losses, especially during hyperemia. This is less the case for resting indices and nonexisting for non-invasive myocardial perfusion imaging. As can be appreciated from Figure 2 and in line with previous reports (14), adverse plaque characteristics seem to have a greater impact on hyperemic intracoronary pressure measures than myocardial blood flow. High-risk plaque morphology is also described to be associated with altered wall shear stress patterns and might affect coronary pressure with greater magnitude in a hyperemic state with maximal flow than in a resting state. Another proposed mechanism of high-risk plaques and abnormal FFR, beyond luminal stenosis, refers to local inability of lipid-rich plaques to dilate at the time of maximal hyperemia (15). Either as a direct result of impaired response to vasodilatory agents or as an indirect effect of increased flow (34), these stenotic vascular segments might show relatively limited vasodilation as compared with unaffected segments. This is possibly owing to a maximally stretched diseased vessel similar to the Glagovian limit (35). CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS. The present results show an interaction between plaque morphology and hyperemic pressure-derived indices of coronary stenosis. As such, atherosclerotic plaques prone for plaque rupture might be less likely to be detected with nonhyperemic pressure indices.

Recently, a simplified prototype algorithm was developed based on a machine-learning method that uses an artificial intelligence algorithm with computational learning to compute the functional severity of a lesion(15)(16)(17). This approach has also been validated against invasively measured FFR in a multicenter registry(18). Both technical solutions involve prior segmentation of the vessel lumen from the contrast enhanced data set before the FFR algorithms aredeployed. Coronary artery calcium (CAC) score affects important components of the FFR calculation: the identification of the vessel lumen and the course of the artery. Yet, limited data from a single study suggested maintained superior diagnostic performance of CT-FFR based on computational fluid dynamics modeling over cCTA, regardless of the overall Agatston score (19). However, the effect of CAC score on the diagnostic performance of the recently introduced machine-learning algorithm requires further investigation. Thus, we sought to investigate the effect of CAC score on the diagnostic performance of machine-learning-based CT-FFR derivation. METHODS STUDY DESIGN AND POPULATION. The rationale and design of the MACHINE registry has been previously described by Coenen et al. (18). Briefly, the MACHINE consortium is a collaboration between 5 institutions in North America, Europe, and Asia that investigates the performance of machinelearning-based CT-FFR compared to cCTA to assess lesion-specific ischemia using invasive FFR as the reference standard in a population suspected of having CAD. Institutional review board approval was obtained at each participating center. Patients were prospectively enrolled at 1 center (20) and retrospectively included based on the availability of both cCTA and invasive FFR data at the 4 other sites (11,12,21,22). Of the 417 patients who initially qualified, 314 patients with 482 vessels were included in the study. Inclusion and exclusion criteria and patient demographics are described in greater detail by Coenen et al. For the noncontrast-enhanced calcium scoring study, a prospectively electrocardiogram (ECG)-triggered acquisition at 55% to 65% of the RR interval with 3-mm section thickness was performed. For the subsequent contrast-enhanced cCTA, a retrospectively ECG-gated protocol or a prospectively ECG-triggered sequential protocol was performed. FIGREF115.text: radiation dose was estimated by multiplying the dose-length-product with a standard conversion factor of 0.014 mSv/mGy$cm(25), resulting in a mean effective radiation dose equivalent of 8.3 AE 6.0 mSv CT-FFR ANALYSIS. For the CT-FFR analysis, a machine-learning-based research prototype (Siemens cFFR, Version 2.1, Siemens, not currently commercially available) was used as previously described(11,12). The software resides on-site on a standarddesktop computer workstation and allows for the physician-driven creation of a patient-specific anatomical model of the coronary tree using a semiautomatic approach. CT-FFR values were computed using a recently introduced machine-learning algorithm (15). This approach is based on a deep learning framework to determine the functional severity of the lesion. The deep learning algorithm uses a multilayer neural network architecture that was trained offline to learn the complex relationship between the anatomy of the coronary tree and its corresponding hemodynamics. The machine-learning algorithm was trained using 12,000 synthetic 3-dimensional (3D) coronary models of various anatomies with known characteristics (vessel maximal and minimal diameter, lesions length, degree of tapering, branch angulation, and so on). These synthetically generated models were then used to further train the artificial intelligence by comparing them to their corresponding hemodynamic conditions as determined via more traditional computational fluid dynamics simulation. This method was previously validated against the computational fluid dynamics algorithm using an independent database of 87 patient-specific anatomical models derived from cCTA in comparison with invasive FFR as the reference standard (15). Based on geometric features of the individual patient's coronary anatomy on cCTA, the algorithm uses the previously learned relationships to calculate the machine learned CT-FFR values. For any point available within the coronary tree, a machine-learned CT-FFR value is generated by computing the ratio of the average local pressure over a cardiac cycle to the average aortic pressure. This results in a color-coded 3D mesh allowing for the determination of the machinelearned CT-FFR value at arbitrary locations. To coregister the correct location of a coronary lesion on cCTA images and 3D CT-FFR coronary meshes, the 18-segment coronary artery model was used (26). Functionally significant CAD was defined as machinelearned CT-FFR #0.80 (11). ICA WITH FFR MEASUREMENT. ICA was performed by experienced interventional cardiologists according to local standards. Invasive FFR measurement was either performed for clinical reasons or for unrelated research purposes. An FFR pressure wire was positioned distal to the stenosis of interest and hyperemia was induced by continuous administration of intravenous adenosine (140 mg /kg/min). FFR values #0.80 were considered hemodynamically significant. To coregister the location of invasive FFR measurement and CT-FFR, an independent observer without knowledge of angiographic or functional results identified the invasive FFR sample location on fluoroscopy images and registered the corresponding location as an anatomical landmark on the cCTA images. Effect of image quality on diagnostic accuracy of noninvasive fractional flow reserve: coronary artery disease, coronary computed tomography angiography, computational fractional flow reserve, invasive coronary angiography APPENDIX For additional case examples, please see the online version of this paper. computational fluid dynamics (CFD) have enabled patient-specific modeling of coronary blood flow and pressure from standard CTA images, without the need for additional imaging or medication (2). Based on this technique, noninvasive fractional flow reserve (FFR) derived from CTA can identify lesion-specific ischemia by invasive coronary angiography (ICA)-derived FFR, as shown in several clinical trials (3-5). Nevertheless, CFD models are complex; involve multiple finely calibrated geometric, hemodynamic, and material parameters; and may require long computation times (6). To address this limitation, Itu et al. (7) developed a machine-learning (ML)-based approach for calculating CT-FFR on-site at standard workstations. The ML algorithm was trained using a database of 12,000 synthetically generated 3-dimensional coronary anatomies for which the CFD-based CT-FFR values were computed. The CFD-based results formed the ground truth training data for the ML-based CT-FFR model. A deep neural network with 28 geometric input features extracted from the synthetically generated database and 4 hidden layers was used to train the ML-based model. The ML application was then tested on CTA images from 87 patients and demonstrated high diagnostic accuracy compared to invasive FFR. The average computation time was 2.4 AE 0.44 s for the entire coronary tree, thus providing near real-time assessment of FFR (7). Coenen et al. (8) compared the diagnostic performance of this ML-based approach against CFD-based CT-FFR in MACHINE (Machine Learning Based CT Angiography Derived FFR: A Multi-Center Registry) (comprising 351 patients and 525 vessels), with invasive FFR as the reference standard. ML-based (area under curve [AUC]: 0.84) and CFD-based CT-FFR (0.84) outperformed visual CTA assessment (0.69; p < 0.001), with no significant difference between the two. The diagnostic accuracy per vessel improved from 58% (54% to 63%) for CTA to 78% (75% to 82%) by adding ML-based CT-FFR. Despite technical advances in CTA resulting in improved temporal and spatial resolution (9), extensive coronary artery calcium (CAC) remains perhaps its greatest challenge in the assessment of coronary artery disease (CAD) (10). The presence of extensive coronary calcification can often lead to overestimation of stenosis severity (11). A meta-analysis of 1,634 patients from 19 studies that examined the influence of CAC on the diagnostic performance of CTA showed a significant decline in the specificity of CTA to 42% (28% to 56%) at CAC scores >400 (12). Extensive CAC also influences accurate segmentation of the vessel lumen, an important component of noninvasive FFR computation. Notwithstanding, a substudy of the NXT (Analysis of Coronary Blood Flow Using CT Angiography: Next Steps) trial by Norgaard et al. (5) found no differences in diagnostic accuracy, sensitivity, or specificity of CFD-based CT-FFR across study-specific quartiles of CAC scoring, including patients at even the highest quartile with CAC scores ranging from 416 to 3,599. (14) report on the impact of CAC on the diagnostic performance of MLbased CT-FFR in a substudy of 314 patients (and 482 vessels) from the MACHINE registry who had available CAC scores from noncontrast CT. Using ML CT-FFR, the authors generated patient-specific 3-dimensional meshes that allowed for determination of the CT-FFR value at any point within the coronary tree. With invasive FFR as reference, 228 vessels in 200 patients had functionally significant coronary stenoses (FFR #0.80). On a per-vessel and per-patient level, the accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity of CT-FFR to detect lesion-specific ischemia were not significantly different across CAC score categories. Per vessel, CT-FFR showed incremental discriminatory power over CTA at both high CAC scores (CAC $400: AUC 0.71 vs. 0.55; p ¼ 0.04) and low-to-intermediate CAC scores (CAC >0 to <400: AUC 0.86 vs. 0.63; p < 0.001). The performance of CT-FFR declined as CAC score increased, just reaching statistical significance (AUC 0.85 [CAC >0 to <400] vs. 0.71 [CAC $400]; p ¼ 0.04).These findings demonstrate the high and superior diagnostic performance of ML-based CT-FFR compared to CTA across a wide range of CAC scores in a large patient cohort, lending further support to the potential role of CT-FFR as a gatekeeper to ICA and coronary revascularization. Although currently a research prototype, the ML-based application is highly promising for the delivery of on-site, real-time FFR assessment. Results derived using the ML model, based on geometric features extracted from CTA, are nearly identical to CFD results, with a >80-fold reduction in computation time compared to CFD. Theoretically, the ML-based FFR calculation may be less influenced by CAC compared to CFD modeling, as the ML algorithm incorporates both local and global geometric data, with only 8 of the 28 input features corresponding to luminal stenosis (7). Moreover, the performance of the ML model likely will improve as advancements are made in the CFD model of coronary arterial flow on which it is based, including refined segmentation algorithms with larger cohorts of real-world CTA data. In recent years, ML in cardiovascular imaging has emerged as a powerful tool for risk prediction and decision making (15). An ML model that combined clinical and anatomic CTA data was shown to predict 5-year all-cause mortality better than existing clinical or CTA metrics alone (16). Furthermore, ML-based CT-FFR in the original MACHINE registry study reclassified 62 of 85 (73%) false-positive CTA results (8), which has important implications for risk stratification and subsequent referral to ICA of patients with suspected CAD. As with all developing artificial intelligence technologies, ML-based CT-FFR has limitations. The study by Tesche et al. (14) revealed a reduction in diagnostic performance of the ML model in patients with CAC $400, which also was reflected by the poor correlation between per-vessel ML-based CT-FFR and invasive FFR in this subgroup (r ¼ 0.35) (14). Certainly, clear thresholds for performing ML-based CT-FFR in the setting of extensive CAC need to be defined before its application in a broad patient population. The extraction of anatomic features from CTA for the ML model also requires considerable time (up to 60 min) (7) and remains the rate-limiting step for on-site CT-FFR at point of care. The present study represents a post hoc analysis of the MACHINE registry data, which were mostly retrospective and included variations in patient selection and study design between centers. In this real-world cohort with a broad range of CAC scores, ML-based CT-FFR improved identification of lesionspecific ischemia even at high CAC scores, with a reduction in performance of CT-FFR with an increase in CAC. Despite the study limitations, Tesche et al. (14) should be commended for their timely work demonstrating the robust diagnostic performance of ML-based CT-FFR in the setting of extensive CAC, the current Achilles heel of coronary CTA. Finally, in a study that randomly assigned patients with suspected CAD to standard or high-resolution CTA, improved CT spatial resolution significantly reduced overestimation of stenosis severity in the setting of calcified plaques and resulted in higher diagnostic accuracy of CTA in comparison to ICA (17). With ongoing advancements in CT technology, the accuracy of coronary tree segmentation and extraction of quantitative measures from CTA are only likely to improve.

Previous studies have shown the prognostic value of perfusion abnormalities detected visually by expert readers on SPECT-MPI for mortality or cardiac events in single-center (3-10) or multicenter studies (11,12). Automated quantitative analysis provides an independent and objective evaluation of MPI on a continuous scale and can grade perfusion defects below the threshold for abnormality. To date, however, the value of quantitative analysis of MPI has not been compared with visual reading in prediction of patient outcomes. The primary objective of this study was to evaluate the prognostic value of quantitative analysis, including images with subtle defects (with findings below standard visual or quantitative abnormality thresholds), by using the multicenter U.S. National Institutes of Health-sponsored REFINE SPECT (REgistry of Fast Myocardial Perfusion Imaging with NExt generation SPECT) study (13), a large registry with recent MPI image data from the latest generation of SPECT scanners. The secondary objective was to compare quantitative analysis to clinical on-site visual reporting in all populations and patients without known CAD.

Visual perfusion abnormality for SPECT imaging under stress (short axis, horizontal long axis, and vertical long axis) was assessed as part of the clinical reporting by experienced boardcertified nuclear cardiologists at each site, with knowledge of all available data, including gated functional data and all clinical information according to routine local protocols. Quantitative perfusion and functional results under stress and at rest in available positions (obtained with site-specific quantification software) were integrated for the final visual determination for the clinical report. Clinical reading scores were provided by overall visual assessment as normal, probably normal, equivocal, or abnormal in sites that did not use segmental scoring (13). For sites using the 17-segment model (n ¼ 13,553) (16,17), the summed stress scores (SSS) were grouped as normal (SSS ¼ 0), probably normal (SSS ¼ 1), equivocal (SSS ¼ 2 to 3), or abnormal (SSS $4) (9). AUTOMATED QUANTIFICATION. All image datasets were de-identified and transferred to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, where quality control was performed by experienced core laboratory technologists without having knowledge of clinical data. Automatically generated myocardial contours generated by Quantitative Perfusion SPECT/Quantitative Gated SPECT software (QPS/QGS, Cedars-Sinai MedicalCenter, Los Angeles, California) were evaluated, and when necessary, contours were adjusted to correspond to the myocardium by an experienced core laboratory technologist(13). Stress and rest images were analyzed as previously described by using total perfusion deficit (TPD)(18,19). TPD was derived from patients in the upright position for D-SPECT scanners and from patients in the supine position for Discovery NM 530c scanners, as these were the default positions recommended for these scanners. Ischemic TPD was defined as the difference of TPD at stress and at rest.

DISCUSSION FINDINGS FROM THE PRESENT STUDY. In this large multicenter REFINE SPECT registry, it was observed that increasing abnormality in both the visual and the automated perfusion quantifications was associated with increased MACE risk over long-term follow-up (median follow-up of 5 years), in both the unadjusted and the adjusted multivariate analyses. The MACE rates increased with each increasing interval of both visual and quantitative assessments (stress TPD) on a fine granular scale, including several intervals below the standard diagnostic threshold (SSS <4 and stress TPD <5%). These findings were observed similarly in the overall population and in patients with suspected CAD. Importantly, quantitative analysis further stratified risk in a significant number of patients with normal visual perfusion assessment or an SSS of 0. Thus, visual and automated quantitative analyses of MPI are complementary to each other in MACE prediction, providing objective information in addition to the overall visual findings. Concordant findings were also observed for the hard event rates, with the hard event rates smaller (as expected) than MACE rates. OTHER STUDIES. Most previous prognostic SPECT-MPI studies have used only visual perfusion assessments (3-12). A few previous prognostic studies of stress SPECT-MPI have used fully automated quantitative analysis. These quantitative studies were limited by a small sample size or have been singlecenter studies. These previous quantitative studies defined death and myocardial infarction as outcomes (22-24), whereas 2 single-center studies followed MACE over a median term of follow-up (25,26). None of the previous prognostic MPI studies directly compared visual with quantitative analyses. VISUAL VERSUS QUANTITATIVE PERFUSION ASSESSMENT. The results of the present study suggest that both visual and quantitative MPI assessments complement each other for risk stratification.

This was also true when adjusted for key confounding variables. The 46% of scans read visually as normal, which also had very low quantitative score (TPD <1%) could be assigned better prognosis than that offered by visual reading alone. A meta-analysis of several prognostic studies with visual analysis that evaluated the prognostic value of normal exercise stress SPECT-MPI in 8,008 patients (27) showed a high negative predictive value of MPI. On the basis of these results, it is likely that negative predictive value of a normal MPI could be further refined with the additional quantitative analysis. CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS. Although readers use all available information to report their final clinical score, gated scans, and clinical data, the authors have found that MACE and risk of hard events (death and myocardial infarction) can be stratified further by standard quantitative perfusion analysis in cases with normal clinical readings in a significant number of patients. Readers and referring physicians should pay attention to perfusion quantification results, even in cases with subtle defects. The quantitative parameters provide additional independent prediction of the patient's outcome. In the future, one could consider reporting a quantitative probability estimation of annual MACE risk for a given patient. Importantly, the present findings indicate that the concordance of normal visual and quantitative findings can actually lower the MACE risk compared with those read only visually, thus avoiding further costly testing and interventions in some patients. Quantitative perfusion should be incorporated by clinicians as an aid before the final interpretation, even if the overall visual finding is normal. This additional prognostic information available from quantitative analysis can be readily obtained in the large volume of MPI performed worldwide annually. These complementary data do not require any additional patient testing, radiation, procedures, or physician time and should be considered during routine evaluation of patient prognosis. CONCLUSIONS Rates of MACE and hard events (death, myocardial infarction) increased progressively with the worsening of perfusion abnormality among patients undergoing stress MPI according to both visual and quantitative analyses. According to quantitative analysis, annualized MACE and hard event rates increased significantly even for perfusion abnormalities below the diagnostic threshold and even for scans reported as normal. Quantitative analysis provides independent and prognostic information that is complementary to visual reading results. O'Connor, PHD b A lthough quantitative techniques for assessing noninvasive and invasive cardiac imaging have been available for years, the cardiology community has been relatively slow to embrace these techniques. The subjective interpretation of images remains the most commonly applied standard in clinical practice. Two parameters that determine the value of cardiac imaging are reproducibility (shooting an arrow multiple times and hitting the same spot on the target) and accuracy (shooting an arrow and hitting the bullseye). For nuclear myocardial perfusion imaging (MPI), quantitative analysis has been shown to enhance reproducibility (1-6). To assess accuracy, the results of imaging need to be compared with an accepted gold standard such as coronary angiography (7) or patient outcomes. In this issue of iJACC, Otaki et al. (8) report the results of a comparison between automated MPI and subjective visual analysis for predicting major adverse cardiac events (MACE) in patients with possible or established coronary artery disease. The authors analyzed MPI in 19,495 patients enrolled in the REFINE SPECT (REgistry of Fast Myocardial Perfusion Imaging with NExt generation SPECT). This registry consists of 5 multinational medical centers that performed technetium-labeled single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) MPI using ultrafast imaging (solid-state detectors) camera systems. Subjective visual analysis was performed at each site by experienced board-certified nuclear cardiologists who had access to clinical and functional data and also sitespecific quantification software to aid in the generation of the clinical report. Quantitative analysis was performed for all images at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center (Los Angeles, California) nuclear cardiology core laboratory by experienced laboratory technologists using standard laboratory software. Patients who underwent early revascularization (#90 days following MPI) were excluded from analysis. Followup data were collected over an average of 4.5 years, applying conventional methodology. MACE occurred in 14.2% of the population and included all-cause mortality (n ¼ 1,341), nonfatal myocardial infarction (MI) (n ¼ 187), unstable angina (n ¼ 207), and late revascularization (n ¼ 1,025).

There are several possibilities to explain the approximately 50% mismatch between visual and quantitative analysis category assignments, including the fact that the same software program may generate different results if the images were processed differently (e.g., selection of different contours) by on-site versus core laboratory technologists; the different quantitation software programs used on-site versus the core laboratory program could produce different results; the on-site nuclear cardiologists generating the final clinical report might have been more strongly influenced by other factors (subjective interpretation of the images, clinical and hemodynamic data, and others) that weighed more heavily than the available on-site quantification results. It would be interesting to know how many patients were enrolled at each site and what on-site software quantitation programs were used, but even knowing this information would not provide a complete answer to this issue. In our previous study comparing intravascular polarimetry with histopathology, we showed that tissue birefringence and depolarization provide useful compositional information and offer advanced tissue characterization(16). The aim of the present study was to investigate,for the first time, the polarization properties of atherosclerotic plaques in patients with coronary artery disease. We explored how the quantitative polarization metrics evaluated in entire cross sections vary among different types of plaques, classified by conventional OFDI according to established qualitative structural criteria (plaque analysis). Moreover, we compared the polarization properties measured locally in the fibrous caps of culprit lesions between patients with ACS and stable angina pectoris (SAP) (cap analysis). METHODS STUDY POPULATION. This first-in-human pilot study of intravascular polarimetry enrolled 30 nonconsecutive patients (ACS, n ¼ 12; SAP, n ¼ 18) undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention at Erasmus University Medical Center between December 2014 and July 2015. The ethics committee at Erasmus University Medical Center approved the protocol, and each patient gave written informed consent before inclusion in the study, which was conducted in compliance with the protocol and the Declaration of Helsinki. PS OFDI was performed using commercial intravascular catheters (FastView, Terumo, Tokyo, Japan) with a custom-built PS OFDI system (Supplemental Appendix), as previously described (15-17). Imaging in the 30 patients yielded a total of 36 pull backs, performed either before the procedure (n ¼ 15; culprit or target vessel, n ¼ 13; nonculprit or nontarget vessel, n ¼ 2) or after the procedure (n ¼ 21). The present study comprises a plaque analysis evaluating entire cross sections evenly distributed along all imaged coronary arteries and a cap analysis focusing solely on the fibrous caps of culprit lesions (Figure 1A). For the plaque analysis, all pull backs were uniformly divided into segments of 5 mm in length, progressing distally and proximally from the culprit lesion (Figure 1B). CONVENTIONAL OFDI ANALYSIS. Two independent investigators (A.K. and L.J.C.Z.) analyzed the conventional OFDI appearance of the selected images using QCU-CMS viewing software (Leiden University Medical Center, Leiden, the Netherlands). Conventional OFDI analysis was performed blinded to the polarimetric signals. Luminal area was measured in all cross sections. Percentage area stenosis was calculated as previously reported (8), taking the mean of the largest lumen within 5 mm proximal and distal to the lesion containing the current cross section as the reference. Each selected cross-section was then categorized as either of normal artery, fibrous plaque (FP), fibrofatty plaque (FF), fibrocalcified plaque (FC), thick-cap fibroatheroma (ThCFA), thin-cap fibroatheroma (TCFA), or plaque rupture (PR), on the basis of the conventional OFDI signal(Figures 2A1 to 2G1). Briefly, a vessel with a tunica intima thinner or similar in thickness to the tunica media was labeled as a normal artery (Figure 2A1). FP was defined as a plaque with high backscattering and relatively homogeneous OFDI signal (Figure 2B1). Plaques with calcium, which appears as a signal-poor or heterogeneous region with a sharply delineated border within fibrous tissue, were classified as FC (Figure 2D1)(9). A plaque with a lipid arc of more than 90 was defined as a fibroatheroma. A lipid-rich plaque with a lipid arc extending <90 was categorized as FF, to appreciate the optical properties of the small lipid-rich area (Figure 2C1). In fibroatheromas, the fibrous cap thickness was measured around its thinnest part 3 times by each observer, and then the averaged value was calculated. If the fibrous cap thickness was <65 mm, the plaque was categorized as TCFA and as ThCFA otherwise. PR was defined as a plaque featuring intimal disruption and cavity formation (Figures 2E1 to 2G1). DISCUSSION This first-in-human pilot study of intravascular polarimetry demonstrates how it augments conventional OFDI plaque characterization with quantitative polarization properties, measured through standard intravascular OFDI catheters simultaneously with the conventional OFDI signal. The polarization features offer refined insight into tissue composition, consistent with our current understanding of the mechanisms involved in plaque progression and destabilization. The major finding of this study is that fibrous caps in ACS culprit lesions and ruptured plaques exhibit lower birefringence compared with the caps of target lesions in SAP patients within our limited study cohort. Compared with the interpretation of conventional OFDI, which relies on subjective identification of qualitative features, polarimetry offers quantitative metrics, leading the way toward objective and

FIGREF167.text: automated characterization of atherosclerotic plaques, which may facilitate the use of intravascular imaging in clinical practice. The improved assessment of plaque composition afforded by the polarization features may provide novel insight into the mechanism of plaque progression and instability Smooth muscle cells and collagen are known to influence the polarization of near infrared light (18). Our recent study of intravascular PS OFDI in cadaveric human hearts revealed that normal intimal tissue exhibits low birefringence compared with intimal tissue in fibrous, early, and advanced atherosclerotic lesions (16). In the present study, we observed significant differences in polarization properties, especially in depolarization, among all plaque types, despite analyzing the entire manually segmented intimal layer, comprising both the angle subtended by the plaque and the remainder of the cross section. Depolarization featured significant differences even among individual plaque types, whereas birefringence was less distinguishing. These observations suggest that PS OFDI provides insight

FIGREF172.text: , birefringence and depolarization of the fibrous cap were associated with increased NSD, suggesting macrophage accumulation. Inflammation is a known mechanism of plaque destabilization(2,22,23). Macrophages release enzymes including matrix metalloproteinases that destroy the extracellular matrix and weaken the cap(22). Our observations suggest that the presence of active macrophages may increase depolarization, whereas the effect of their presence causes a reduction in birefringence.The physical mechanism inducing depolarization in atherosclerosis remains to be elucidated. We speculate that lipid droplets exceeding the size of the wavelength used for OFDI and small cholesterol crystals, which have been postulated to be a crucial factor in the initiation of inflammatory response in atherosclerosis(24), are the origin of the observed depolarization.Consistent with our previous cadaveric human heart study of intravascular polarimetry(16), we observed that calcifications located in fibrous tissue exhibited lower birefringence and depolarization than those in lipid-rich lesions. Although the OFDI appearance of microcalcifications has not been established (6), we speculate that their presence in fibrous caps contributes to a reduction of the cap birefringence, together with a lack of collagen organization and content and absence of smooth muscle cells. The few occurrences of white thrombus in the present study had minimal impact on the underlying polarization signatures. However, the stronger attenuation of red thrombus may lead to an apparent increase in depolarization that would impair interpretation of the underlying vessel wall, similar to conventional OFDI. STUDY LIMITATIONS. First, our study consisted of a small number of patients from a cohort of nonconsecutive patients and was cross-sectional in design. Considering potential selection bias of patients, our findings should be interpreted with caution, although we included all patients imaged with intravascular polarimetry. Furthermore, the limited number may have led to a potential overestimation of the differences between polarization features when performing multiple pairwise comparisons and prevented multivariate analysis. Because of its compatibility with clinical OFDI catheters, intravascular polarimetry can be readily applied to any patient eligible for conventional OFDI, and future well-designed studies are needed to ascertain our current findings.

FIGREF173.text: , clear identification of fibroatheromas with OCT or OFDI remains debatable. Combination of intravascular ultrasound and OCT or OFDI has been shown to improve diagnostic accuracy of identifying fibroatheromas (13). Future histopathologic validation studies are needed to inspect the ability of polarization properties to distinguish between different plaque types and potentially enable automated plaque classification.Third, we observed that the NSD was associated with depolarization in the focal fibrous caps but not in the entire caps. Macrophage infiltration frequently occurs very locally, and averaging the signals across entire caps carries less meaning than across a local region of interest. Moreover, the required normalization of the NSD depends delicately on the ROI, and evidence supporting the NSD metric remains scant.We suspect that both NSD and depolarization capture aspects of macrophage infiltration, but validation studies with histology are needed to identify how depolarization relates to macrophage infiltration.Finally, no patient in the present study had plaque erosion, the second most common cause of ACS. CONCLUSIONS This study presents polarization properties of coronary atherosclerotic lesions in patients with coronary artery disease. The fibrous caps of culprit lesions in patients with ACS and/or PR featured lower birefringence than in those with SAP. When averaged across entire cross sections, the polarimetric signals varied among distinct morphological plaque subtypes. Quantitative assessment of plaque polarization properties by intravascular polarimetry may open new avenues for studying plaque composition and detecting high-risk patients. Prospective studies in larger populations are needed to evaluate how polarization metrics could translate into improved patient outcomes and optimized medical therapy compared with using only the structural features available to conventional OFDI. Albaghdadi, MD, MSC I ntracoronary imaging techniques provide unique insights into the pathobiology and treatment of human coronary artery disease (CAD) (1-5). The "holy grail" of intracoronary imaging is to identify high-risk, or "vulnerable," plaques that are associated with an inevitable future clinical event, such as myocardial infarction. On the basis of seminal studies demonstrating the association of in vivo plaque composition with the pathology of acute coronary syndromes (ACS) (6,7), investigators have directed their efforts toward the characterization of plaque composition using a variety of intracoronary imaging techniques (8).

FIGREF175.text: In this issue of iJACC, Otsuka et al. (12) validate a new first-in-human intravascular approach to image coronary plaque polarization, a unique optical property of atherosclerosis. These investigators have previously demonstrated that 2 features related to the polarization of light, birefringence and depolarization, are operative in human coronary plaques, and can be detected ex vivo via an intravascular polarization-sensitive (PS)-OCT/optical frequency domain imaging (OFDI) catheter-based system (13).Birefringence is a measure of optical anisotropy, or the difference in the refractive index of light polarized (oriented) parallel and perpendicular to the plaque tissue. In plaque, the degree of birefringence reflects the amount of collagen and smooth muscle cell (SMC) content(14). Depolarization refers to how quickly polarized light returns to a depolarized (randomly oriented) state, and potentially reflects the content of lipid particles, macrophage accumulation, or cholesterol crystals. In the context of high-risk plaque features such as a thin-cap fibroatheroma(TCFA), the investigators previously demonstrated ex vivo that PS-OFDI-derived low birefringence indicates low collagen/SMC content, and high depolarization indicates high amounts of lipid/macrophages/ cholesterol crystals (13). In this current report, the investigators extend their prior ex vivo study by demonstrating the feasibility of performing intracoronary PS-OFDI in 12 patients with ACS and in 18 patients with stable angina. The investigators first demonstrated that in culprit lesions, ACS lesions exhibited lower birefringence (lower collagen/SMC content) in the plaque, total fibrous cap, and focal fibrous cap zones, as compared with stable CAD lesions. In addition, in the thinnest part of the fibrous cap (focal cap analysis), culprit ACS lesions exhibited higher depolarization rates (putatively, higher lipid/macrophages/cholesterol crystal content), compared with stable lesions. This SEE PAGE 790 difference was not observed when the entire fibrous cap was analyzed, however. Patients with ACS also displayed a significantly lower minimum fibrous cap thickness (219 mm vs. 291 mm), as expected. Next, to examine differences in polarization of culprit lesions on the basis of their pathological subtype, 342 selected PS-OFDI cross-sectional images were classified as normal artery (n ¼ 31), fibrous plaque (n ¼ 84), fibro-fatty (n ¼ 45), fibrocalcific (n ¼ 81), thick-cap fibroatheroma (n ¼ 88), TCFA (n ¼ 11), or plaque rupture (PR) (n ¼ 2). The investigators observed for the first time in living patients that depolarization properties differed between various plaque types, with fibrous plaque producing the highest birefringence, and normal artery producing the lowest birefringence. However, there were no unique differences in birefringence for TCFA or PR compared with other subtypes, in part, possibly due to low sample size, but also indicating that birefringence may not be an easily usable classifier to identify high-risk plaque subtypes. It remains to be determined whether birefringence measures could refine the rupture risk of OCTidentified TCFAs, namely, that for a TCFA with a given fibrous cap thickness, lower birefringence might indicate greater instability (lower collagen/SMC content), as suggested by the investigators' generalized estimating equation model. With respect to depolarization, the investigators demonstrated the lowest rates of depolarization in normal and fibrous plaques, and the highest rates in TCFA or PR (albeit with limited sample size). Similar to the preceding comments for birefringence, it remains to be determined for a given TCFA whether a higher rate of depolarization will predict a higher risk of future plaque rupture, as was also suggested by the generalized estimating equation model, demonstrating an association of depolarization with OCTderived plaque macrophages. In summary, the investigators should be congratulated for advancing the field of intracoronary optical imaging-based plaque characterization, and in particular for developing a clinical intravascular imaging system and approach in an academic environment. As a next step, longitudinal outcome studies are needed to determine the potential additive clinical value of PS-OFDI beyond conventional OCT. Mechanisms of atherothrombosis and vascular response to primary percutaneous coronary intervention in women versus men with acute myocardial infarction: results of R uptured thin-cap fibroatheromas (TCFAs), frequently implicated at the site of culprit coronary thrombi, are hallmarked by the presence of a thin, inflamed fibrous cap overlying a large necrotic lipid core (1,2). Motivated by the need to identify rupture-prone plaques prospectively in patients, a number of intravascular modalities, including optical frequency domain imaging (OFDI), virtual histology, intravascular ultrasound (IVUS), and near-infrared spectroscopy, have been investigated to detect TCFAs (3,4). A critical challenge is that TCFAs with similar morphological features do not all possess an equal likelihood of rupture. In 70% of patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), multiple nondisrupted TCFAs are found remote from the culprit site and in nonculprit arteries (5,6). Moreover, 20% of plaque ruptures are observed in necrotic core (NC) lesions with thicker fibrous caps (>100 mm), intraplaque hemorrhage, or calcifications (5-7). These findings call into question the effectiveness of an imaging paradigm that relies entirely on detecting TCFA features and highlight the need to augment morphological findings with critical biomechanical metrics to evaluate the risk of plaque rupture accurately.

CONCLUSIONS We present a novel and straightforward approach to estimate peak stress in coronary plaques. With a simple analytical equation that defines the cumulative influence of 2-dimensional plaque geometry, we demonstrated that the PSM could be accurately estimated, which may potentially serve as a pivotal biomechanical indicator of plaque rupture risk in patients. Consequently, this new approach obviates the need for tedious and mathematically intensive FEM. In the future, we anticipate that the MSE could be used in conjunction with routine OFDI and IVUS evaluation, which will enable further investigation into the relationship between biomechanical stress profiling and subsequent plaque-related events. Fotiadis, PHD b,c T he past few decades have witnessed extensive investigations to risk-stratify individual coronary artery plaques in an effort to identify plaques likely to progress, destabilize, and cause a new major adverse cardiac event, so that potentially life-saving intervention strategies could be preemptively deployed. Initial investigations focused primarily on anatomic characterization of plaque morphology, but long-term outcomes studies underscored that although anatomic characterization of plaques was an essential foundation to understand current and future plaque behavior, the predictive value of plaque anatomic features alone is low (1-4). Multiple animal and human natural history studies demonstrated that the natural history of individual plaques is remarkably heterogeneous over time (5,6), and the majority of ostensibly high-risk plaques by anatomic features remain quiescent and do not destabilize, perhaps related to arterial compensatory remodeling (5,7). It has become clear that additional features of atherosclerosis vascular biology beyond anatomy are critically contributing to the ongoing natural history of individual plaques. A major thrust of more recent basic and translational research has, therefore, focused on the biomechanical forces affecting the plaque, because these pathobiological processes may provide the crucial incremental stimulus that determines whether an individual plaque will progress, destabilize, or become quiescent (8-10). Plaque rupture occurs when the biomechanical forces affecting the plaque exceed the strength of the material properties of the plaque and its constituents (plaque structural stress [PSS]) (10), and recent studies have indicated that assessment of PSS, based on virtual histology-intravascular ultrasounds (IVUS) features, is associated with increased likelihood of plaque rupture (11). Yet these studies typically require extensive post-processing that are both time-and resource-intensive, and have not been feasible for routine clinical use. Computational modeling has been widely used in arterial flow simulations using idealized geometries or geometrical models obtained in a personalized manner though image segmentation and 3-dimensional reconstruction methods from various imaging modalities, such as coronary angiography, IVUS, optical coherence tomography, and coronary computed tomography angiography, which are widely used in clinical practice(12,13). Some of these imaging modalities can depict in detail the composition of the plaque, as well as its geometry, which can be further used in the modeling of the blood flow(14).IVUS in particular can provide details on plaque composition, which, combined with the morphology, can guide the understanding of its vulnerable behavior. Several computational studies focused initially on the computation of endothelial shear stress (ESS), which can be used as a metric to detect areas of low ESS, where atherosclerotic plaque is prone to develop and progress, or the low or high ESS,

They determined an excellent correlation between this metric and the finite element-derived peak stress. They also assessed the ability of this metric to locate the site of plaque rupture using data from 3 patients. Such an approach would be very favorable for clinical management and interventional cardiologists, because it requires only segmentation and extraction of 6 features, which can be performed manually, requires no expertise on finite elements, and requires only the use of a closed form equation. It is also much faster because it avoids finite element calculations that, depending on the complexity of the arterial morphology, may require extensive computational time. The evaluation presented in the investigators' work is limited and may not cover the full range of stress peak values where this metric is valid. In that respect, this methodological approach needs further validation with various artery/plaque morphologies and range of peak stress values, as well as localization of rupture prone sites. This multifactorial metric described by Doradla et al. These stresses include the axial plaque stress, derived from the plaque longitudinal intraluminal geometry (16) or the local ESS that serves as a pro-inflammatory stimulus to increase degrading proteases within the high-risk plaque that weaken the internal structures and render it physically more susceptible to rupture (8,9). Broader multifactorial biomechanical stress metrics in the future may even be associated with greater prognostic value as more biologically meaningful forces are incorporated, especially if they can be rapidly assessed. HISTORICAL BACKGROUND AF is the most common rhythm disorder observed in 2% of the general population and the prevalence is further increasing as the society is aging (1,2). It is well known that atrial fibrillation (AF) causes left atrial (LA) and mitral annular dilatation without left ventricular (LV) dysfunction (3-5). However, whether AF and succeeding annular dilatation cause significant mitral regurgitation (MR) without LV dysfunction remains controversial. It had been widely recognized that MR can occur without significant degenerative changes of the mitral leaflets in patients with severe left heart dilatation or LV dysfunction caused either by ischemic heart disease or idiopathic myocardial disease. These types of MR were called functional (secondary) MR in contrast to degenerative (primary) MR caused by the organic change of mitral valve itself (6). RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN MECHANISMS. Importantly, each of the mechanisms discussed so far relate to 1 aspect of "atrial remodeling" seen in patients with advanced AF. In other words, these various structural and functional changes caused by AF usually progress simultaneously. As shown in the Central Illustration, structural changes start with LA and annular dilatation, which are accompanied by flattening of saddle shape of the annulus. Annular dilatation, at least in part, seems to play a role in leaflet remodeling, which attenuates the annulus area to leaflet area imbalance. Functionally, AF reduces annulus contractility, which results in a larger systolic annulus area and worsens the annulus area to leaflet area imbalance. LA dysfunction is further accelerated by MR and is associated with worse clinical outcomes. These changes progress simultaneously in most cases, making it difficult to assess the net influence of each factor. Some studies used a statistical approach to adjust for confounders (Table 2); however, unfortunately, there has been no study that considers all the possible mechanisms together with an appropriate statistical approach and a sufficient sample size. It should therefore be acknowledged that this relationship remains theoretical speculation and it is not fully understood whether each factor is just a bystander or an important trigger influencing prognosis. Several morphological aspects, such as bileaflet MVP with diffuse leaflet redundancy and thickening (due to accumulation of proteoglycans through the spongiosa), chordae elongation, and annular dilation, electrocardiographic abnormalities, severity of mitral valve regurgitation, and LV dysfunction have been associated with arrhythmias in MVP (12). An anatomic substrate for promoting electric instability was described by Sanfilippo et al. (13) and subsequently by Han et al. (14). These investigators demonstrated the presence of LGE on valve leaflets (indicating the expansion of spongiosa due to proteoglycans accumulations) and on the tips of papillary muscles (indicating fibrosis). Interestingly, the presence of fibrosis at the papillary muscles tip was more often observed in a subgroup of patients with arrhythmic MVP. More recently, Basso et al. (15) confirmed and extended these observations. In 43 young patients (age range 10 to 40 years) with MVP and myxomatous valve who died of sudden cardiac death, the investigators found patches of replacement-type fibrosis on papillary muscles and on subendocardial-midmural layers of basal posterior wall, just below the posterior valve leaflet (Videos 2 and 3). They hypothesized that systolic mechanical stretch of myocardium closed to the mitral valve might have accounted for injuries, eventually leading to replacement-type fibrosis. Marra et al. (16) provided further evidence for this hypothesis, finding that mitral annular disjunction, defined as a separation between the left atrial (LA) wall-mitral hinge line and the LV free wall, is a constant feature in patients with arrhythmic MVP (Figure 4). They hypothesized that this peculiar morphological aspect might contribute to the systolic stretch of the myocardium close to the valve and, as a result, to the propensity to develop regional LV fibrosis and electric instability. According to their conclusions, the genesis of malignant arrhythmias in MVP may be recognized in the deadly combination of a substrate (papillary muscle tips and basal free wall myocardial fibrosis) and a trigger (i.e., myocardial stretch exacerbated by mitral annular dysfunction) (Figure 5). Maurer, MD, a Milton Packer, MD b,c T he most direct metric of the systolic performance of the heart is the quantity of blood ejected by the left ventricle during a single systole (i.e., the stroke volume). The stroke volume adapts rapidly to both internal homeostatic requirements and external stresses. If ventricular filling were suddenly limited (as in the case of a ventricular extrasystole), the resulting acute distension of the heart's chambers would serve to enhance the shortening of the next systole (through the Frank-Starling mechanism), thus serving to prevent ventricular overfilling. Similarly, if the sympathetic nervous system is activated (as during exercise), stroke volume increases, not only because of the recruitment of blood volume from peripheral reservoirs, but also because adrenergic stimulation augments the shortening of cardiomyocytes. These short-term adaptations ensure that stroke volume can change rapidly to provide adequate oxygen delivery to the periphery, while avoiding increases in pulmonary venous pressures.

When properly performed, the calculation of myocardial volume is the same whether performed during systole or diastole; because myocardial tissue is not compressible, myocardial volume does not change during contraction(3). Importantly, the MCF is a measure of the degree to which the myocardium contracts during systole (assessed by stroke volume) when considered in relation to its capacity to contract (assessed by myocardial volume)(1,2). As a result, the MCF represents a generalized measure of myocardial shortening. Conceptually, the MCF is very similar to myocardial strain; however, strain measures shortening in a localized segment of the heart, whereas the MCF synthesizes information about shortening in all domains (longitudinal, radial, and circumferential) and expresses the sum in a single measurement(2).Being a composite measure, the MCF does not consider the timing of myocardial shortening, whereas strain can be quantified throughout the cardiac cycle (i.e., the timing of strain [the strain rate] can be calculated).The most commonly used metric of left ventricular systolic performance in clinical practice, the left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), also relies on stroke volume. However, when the LVEF is calculated, the stroke volume is normalized for (i.e., divided by) the left ventricular end-diastolic volume (LVEDV) rather than the myocardial volume. The normalization of stroke volume for the LVEDV is based on the inherent assumption that the LVEDV is an important driver of stroke volume. That assumption may be valid at extremely short time intervals when small increases in LVEDV act to enhance the force of the next systole (as in the Frank-Starling mechanism). However, the LVEDV is not a primary mechanism of enhancing stroke volume during longterm adaptations seen in human health and disease. More importantly, the ratio of stroke volume to LVEDV is not a direct measure of myocardial shortening, and changes in the ratio do not reflect changes in the degree of myocardial shortening; in fact, measurements relating to the myocardium are not included in determination of the LVEF (4).
